hedline.hl1: New Hulk of the Road: 7,000 Pounds of Ego

abstract.p: Sam Goldman letter, commenting on August 6 article, says plan by General Motors to produce 7,000-pound-plus Hummer sports utility vehicle exemplifies total disdain for public safety and environment; drawing

block.p: Re ''G.M. Has High Hopes for Vehicle Truly Meant for Road Warriors'' (front page, Aug. 6):

If any decision exemplifies a company's total disdain for the public safety and the environment, it is that of General Motors to proceed with the full-scale production of the 7,000-plus-pound Hummer, a version of the Humvee, the military transport used in the Persian Gulf war.
Re ''G.M. Has High Hopes for Vehicle Truly Meant for Road Warriors'' (front page, Aug. 6):

If any decision exemplifies a company's total disdain for the public safety and the environment, it is that of General Motors to proceed with the full-scale production of the 7,000-plus-pound Hummer, a version of the Humvee, the military transport used in the Persian Gulf war.

Here is a vehicle that will use too much fuel, emit far more pollutants than cars do, block the vision of vehicles driving behind it, and with its seven-foot width stick out further than normal into the street when it is parked. Certainly, this is not what already congested New York streets (and those of other urban areas) need.

What also points out G.M.'s lack of concern for our society is the statement by the company's director of North American vehicle safety. You report that he said his office had played little role in the Hummer's planning and design. What an egregious example of corporate irresponsibility!
SAM GOLDMAN Huntington Station, N.Y., Aug. 6, 2000
